Body:
Meteor.js is a new framework for real-time web applications. Meteor follows a publish/subscribe pattern effectively recreating a local database with just the subset of data the user is allowed to see. This frees the developer to write database queries both on the client and server.

To bring everyone up to speed on subscriptions before my demo, we watched Matt Debergalis’ video on Meteor.js. The video described how you can subscribe to different channels and make the channels very specific. He also goes into some details about how the security works.

In this video I explain how to structure a Meteor.js application for people familiar with MVC frameworks such as Rails. I use the minimongoid package and coffeescript for powerful models and Iron Router for routing and controllers.

I encourage anyone who is interested in learning more about Meteor.js to watch the demo and feel free to comment on the video if you have any additional questions for Michael. Here is the source code if you would like to try it out yourself:  https://github.com/elfassy/cookbook
